abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts only modest. Several lessons are drawn
            from the project. First, the existing current demand for
            financial services, both in urban, and rural areas needs to
            be met, but, the Government should provide an enabling
            environment, and design a strategy based on decentralized
            financial institutions, to effectively reduce poverty.
            Second, the need for transforming savings into secure loans,
            and ensuring financial autonomy is an enormous challenge,
            however, good governance and enforcement of monetary, and
            economic policies, (within an adequate legal framework), can
            lay the foundation for a sustainable growth and development.
            Regrettably, as demonstrated by the implementation of the
            project, there is a prevailing weak support within the
            government, contrary to the country's potential to
            accomplish sustainability, provided it is adequately helped.
            Third, centralized savings and loans institutions perform
            inefficiently, generating high operating costs, thus making
            decisions at the local level difficult to implement, and,
            the lack of local management systems contributes to a
            certain extent, to the high increase of overdue loans.
            Nonetheless, these shortcomings will be professionally taken
            care of through financial, and institutional audits to be
            undertaken soon, and, the weak human resource management in
            most credit union networks, can be mitigated by making
            social interactions a central element of the development process.
